newsitem.title: USA: Judgmental forecasts dwarf economic models at Fed.
newsitem.headline: Judgmental forecasts dwarf economic models at Fed.

text.p: Although the Federal Reserve has traditionally relied on macroeconomic models for its decisions, policy makers are turning increasingly to "judgmental forecasts", sources at the Fed said.

The shift towards putting a higher degree of interpretation on data has occured because broad technological changes have thrown into question the ability of the models to gauge productivity gains accurately, they said.
This is mainly a problem in the latest sector to benefit from the computer revolution, the service sector, they added.
"The relationship has basically broken down," one Fed source told Reuters.
The source, refering to the relation between growth and inflation, said "the question is whether a structural shift (in the economy) has actually occurred."

The source said central bankers are heavily relying on judgmental forecasts because it is difficult to gauge the impact on the huge economy of massive business investments in cost-saving new technologies.
"Productivity gains in the service sector are particularly difficult to gauge," he said.

"The models are equations to estimate the behavior of key relationships for the economy, based on data going as far back as possible," the source said. "The longer the period, the better the forecast is, provided there has not been a kind of structural shift during the period studied."
The source said pointed out that the U.S. economy may be more efficient today due to the many technological innovations that have reached a broad spectrum of business activity.
"By the same token the Consumer Price Index may overstate inflation, productivity may be understated," the source said.
Another Fed source said the Fed Board's models, which are based on economic series running back several decades, "may have too much historic relationship embedded with them."
"The Fed tends to put less weight on the models as opposed to a judgmental approach," he said.

According to the sources, the models were put to the test in early 1995 when data, based on historic performance, continued to signal the possibility of inflationary pressures coming from a year marked by strong growth.
Alan Blinder, an expert on inventories who was Fed Vice-Chairman at the time, was the first to point to the risk of a slowdown.
The Fed, ending a rapid-fire preemptive tightening cycle, lowered the federal funds rate three times between July 1995 and January 1996.

"Macroeconomic models are useful tools, but the truth of the matter is that the ability to condense the behavior of 250 million into a set of 50 or 100 equations is still limited," the second source said.
He agreed the central issue in the U.S. economy today may be the understatement of productivity "which would allow to place potential growth at a higher level."
A more efficient economy would also allow for a lower unemployment rate to prevail over an extended period without fueling inflationary pressures.
